Dear Mrs. Smillie:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on December
16, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. /DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of eight foster home files reviewed did not have the reevaluation completed at
least 15 days prior to the expiration date of the foster home license as required.
File one: license expired on 4/5/2021 and the reevaluation was completed on
4/5/2021.
Filed two: license expired on 3/5/2021 and the reevaluation was completed on
3/3/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan completed
every 90 calendar days.
File one: USP due on 11/30/2021 and had not been started at the time of case read
on 12/6/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/12/2021
1216/2019 INTERIM, CAP approved 1/21/2020
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at
least once every month.
4

Two of six foster care files reviewed were missing the required monthly face-to-face
visit with the foster child and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home.
File one: There was no documentation that the required visit with the foster child
occurred in October in the foster placement
File two: There was no documentation that the required visit with the foster child
occurred in March in the foster placement.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Initial medical passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date
Updated medical passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as required.
File one: Medical passports were not updated quarterly. There was not an updated
medical passport since September 2020.
File two: Medical passports were not updated quarterly. There was not an updated
medical passport between 5/19/2021-11/29/2021
File three: Initial medical passport not provided to foster placement within 14 days of
removal. Child was removed on 10/15/2021 and initial medical passport provided on
11/12/2021.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
5

Three of six foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
File one: 4/19/2021 USP approved 5/12/2021; 7/17/2021 USP approved 8/3/2021
File two: 9/12/2021 USP approved 9/28/2021
File three: 6/14/2021 USP approved 6/29/2021
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care cases,
the local DHS office designee.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the PATP.
File one: 3/5/2021 PATP missing caregiver signature.
File two: 3/17/2021 PATP missing youth signature.
File three: 9/24/2021 PATP signature did not obtain foster parents’ signature timely.
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster
care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker:
 Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement.
 Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
 Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
 Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental,
mental health and other needs and takes appropriate
action or offers services in response to the identified
needs of each child.
 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives,
and the child's permanency plan, in a developmentally
6

appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions
and express viewpoints.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
File one: there was not documentation that a quality visit occurred in May and
November.
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in MISACWIS within five business days
of the contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-
face contacts.
Three of six foster care files reviewed contained contacts that were not entered within
five business days.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined
in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: 6/3/2021 USP and 9/1/2021 USP did not have corresponding FTM’s.
File two: 12/30/2020 USP and 3/30/2021 USP did not have corresponding FTM’s.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
7

Three of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
SRM 200 Fingerprints
Personnel Training
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years
thereafter. CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes SAT timely.
Based on review of the SRM 200 spreadsheet, one current employee was found to be
in non-compliance to timely certification of Security Awareness Training (SAT).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/12/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Referrals to adoption-document cases that are referred but incomplete.
Follow up with referring agency and document all attempts to obtain the
information necessary to complete the application.
 Document on the signature page of PATP and/or medical passport when
attempting to obtain required signature but not returned.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Supervisory approval-utilize outlook calendar to keep track of reports that are
sent back to staff for corrections.
 Contacts-utilize outlook calendar as a reminder for staff to enter contacts or
complete contacts.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 6/24/2021 determined the foster parents were
restraining the child when he refused to go to bed at night. The family was found to
be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A Corrective Action Plan was
implemented, and the foster parents have initiated the steps outlined in the
Corrective Action Plan. The foster parents are no longer considered for placements
through the Transitional Foster Care program at this time.
8

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2020 Renewal
Inspection Report. During this period under review the agency expressed the impact
that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall compliance. Two citations were noted
as repeat violations in the current inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported that the agency experienced some struggles related to
COVID-19 and changing safety precautions as well as some staffing issues. The
Chief Administrator (CA) reported the previous year CAP was effective and there are
good systems in place, but she did note that some areas of the CAP, such as
relative engagement in the licensing process, was more challenging. In addition,
delays in fingerprinting was also a challenge for the agency in the last review period.
The CA indicated that the management team works very diligently to maintain
compliance. Specifically, the agency makes small adjustments to internal processes
as needed to ensure that small details are not overlooked. They have developed
spreadsheets for tracking that are efficient and simplified enough for staff to
assimilate.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff reported some
challenges related to COVID-19 but, overall, things have gone well over the past
review period. Staff reported that they have regularly scheduled team meetings as
well as supervision meetings and supervisors are almost always available outside of
the scheduled meetings. Staff reported that the agency utilizes checklists that they
feel have been helpful to maintain compliance and organization.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
9

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
